newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Kiev local favouritism seen spurring Motorola exit.
newsitem.headline: Kiev local favouritism seen spurring Motorola exit.

text.p: U.S. technology group Motorola Inc's pull-out from a large mobile telephone network project in Ukraine came as no surprise to analysts who say Kiev has been playing favourites with local companies.
"What this does is takes the real players out and lets the guys on the fringe come in and take over," said one Western analyst on Tuesday.

Motorola announced last week that it would pull the plug on a project to launch a GSM 900 (global system for mobile communications) phone network with its local partner Ukrainian Radio Systems (URS). Motorola owned 49 percent of the venture.

Foreign investors have viewed the former Soviet republic's underdeveloped telecommunications system as a potentially lucrative opportunity but complain about deterrents such as inconsistent laws, corruption and high taxes.

"There were ever-changing terms and conditions," said Motorola country manager Gregory Perchatsch, who declined to provide further details but said his company had invested several million dollars in setting up the system.
A Ukrainian Communications Ministry spokesman countered: "There were equal conditions for the tender. Why isn't Motorola happy when the other two winners are? It's Motorola's problem."

Motorola plans to continue participating in a local GSM 1800 network and to sell telecommunications equipment but it had forecast investing $500 million in the next 15 years to supply equipment and to back URS.
Under Ukrainian law only local companies are entitled to frequencies.
The Western analyst said Motorola had quit in reaction to the tender process for frequencies, which has been drawn out and reportedly seen frequency prices hiked.
"They just said they're not playing this game anymore," the analyst said.
Three firms, including two foreign joint ventures and one newly-created Ukrainian company, won tenders in February.

But the Ukrainian government said it would not allocate frequencies for another five months because the companies -- URS-Motorola, Ukrainian Mobile Communications (UMC) and Kiev Star -- were not equally ready to begin.
The analyst said Kiev Star, an unknown concern started last year and thought to be the parent of a Kiev newspaper, needed to find financial backing and equipment.
"Kiev Star wouldn't survive without the five months," he said.
Motorola opened its representative office in Ukraine in late 1993 and UMC was formed in 1992.
UMC, owned by the state, Deutsche Telekom AG, Tele Danmark AS and Koninklijke PTT Nederland NV (Dutch PTT), threatened to withdraw after the government raised tariffs last year.
Some company officials at the time accused Ukraine of shutting out Western competitors from the GSM market.
"Three companies cannot share the frequencies that are available," said another analyst. "There was only enough room for two operators."
Although the tender fees were not disclosed, media reports said the government hiked the per frequency rate to $65 million from under $10 million.
Ukraine has attracted only $1.4 billion in direct foreign investment since independence five years ago and the government has been slow to address investors' complaints.
Roman Shpek, chief of the state-run National Agency for Reconstruction and Development, said it was unfortunate that Motorola was pulling out.
"But all the same there were three winners of the tender and two are still here," Shpek said.
Motorola has promised to try to find a partner for URS.
URS president Volodymyr Vernyck said Motorola had its reasons for leaving but would not stop his company's activities. "We will carry on as before," he said.
